sen.j: 一色 義直（いっしき よしなお、永享3年（1431年） - 没年不詳）は室町時代の大名（守護大名）。
sen.e: Yoshinao ISSHIKI (1431 - Date of his death not known) was a shugodaimyo (warlord stemmed from a regional governor) who lived in the Muromachi Period.
Yoshinao ISSHIKI (1431 - Date of his death not known) was a shugodaimyo (warlord stemmed from a regional governor) who lived in the Muromachi Period.
Yoshinao ISSHIKI (1431 - Date of his death not known) was a shugodaimyo (warlord stemmed from a regional governor) who lived in the Muromachi period.

sen.j: 一色義貫の嫡男。
sen.e: He was the heir of Yoshitsura ISSHIKI.
He was the heir of Yoshitsura ISSHIKI.
He was the heir of Yoshitsura ISSHIKI.

sen.j: 幼名千徳丸。
sen.e: His childhood name was Sentokumaru.
His childhood name was Sentokumaru.
His childhood name was Sentokumaru.

sen.j: 官途は従四位下、左京大夫、修理大夫。
sen.e: His rank and position were Jushiinoge (Junior Fourth Rank, Lower Grade), Sakyo no Daibu (Master of the Western Capital) and Shuridaibu (traditional office head).
His rank and position were Jushiinoge (Junior Fourth Rank, Lower Grade), Sakyo no Daibu (Master of the Western Capital) and Shuridaibu (traditional office head).
His rank and position were Jushiinoge (Junior Fourth Rank, Lower Grade), Sakyo no Daibu (Master of the Western Capital) and Shuri no Daibu (Master of the Office of Palace Repairs).
sen.cmt: Shuridaibu→Shuri no Daibuとし、補足修正

sen.j: 丹後国・伊勢国半国守護、尾張国知多郡・三河国渥美郡。
sen.e: Shugo (military governor) for Tango Province and a half of Ise Province, Chita District, Owari Province and Atsumi District, Mikawa Province
Shugo (military governor) for Tango Province and a half of Ise Province, Chita District, Owari Province and Atsumi District, Mikawa Province
Shugo (military governor) for Tango Province and a half of Ise Province, Chita District, Owari Province and Atsumi District, Mikawa Province.

sen.j: 子は一色義春、一色義秀、斯波義寛室。
sen.e: He had three children, Yoshiharu ISSHIKI, Yoshihide ISSHIKI and the wife of Yoshihiro SHIBA.
He had three children, Yoshiharu ISSHIKI, Yoshihide ISSHIKI and the wife of Yoshihiro SHIBA.
He had three children, Yoshiharu ISSHIKI, Yoshihide ISSHIKI and the wife of Yoshihiro SHIBA.

sen.j: 養子に一色政熈（上杉教朝実子）。
sen.e: He had an adopted son, Masahiro ISSHIKI (real child of Noritomo UESUGI).
He had an adopted son, Masahiro ISSHIKI (real child of Noritomo UESUGI).
He had an adopted son, Masahiro ISSHIKI (real child of Noritomo UESUGI).

sen.j: 弟に一色義遠。
sen.e: Yoshito ISSHIKI was his younger brother.
Yoshito ISSHIKI was his younger brother.
Yoshito ISSHIKI was his younger brother.

sen.j: 永享12年（1440年）に父義貫が大和国の陣中で足利義教の命を受けた武田信栄により殺害されると、一色氏の惣領には義教の寵臣で庶流の一色教親が就く。
sen.e: When his father, Yoshitsura was killed in the ranks in Yamato Province by Nobuhide TAKEDA under the instruction by Yoshinori ASHIKAGA in 1440, the position of the head of the Isshiki family was assumed by Norichika ISSHIKI, who was from the branch line and a favorite subject of Yoshinori.

When his father, Yoshitsura was killed in the ranks in Yamato Province by Nobuhide TAKEDA under the instruction by Yoshinori ASHIKAGA in 1440, the position of the head of the Isshiki family was assumed by Norichika ISSHIKI, who was from the branch line and a favorite subject of Yoshinori.

When his father, Yoshitsura was killed in the ranks in Yamato Province by Nobuhide TAKEDA under the instruction by Yoshinori ASHIKAGA in 1440, the position of the head of the Isshiki family was assumed by Norichika ISSHIKI, who was from the branch line and a favorite subject of Yoshinori.

sen.j: しかし、義貫の遺臣はその後も一色家嫡流の復興を訴え、各地で蜂起を繰り返す。
sen.e: Even after that, however, ishin (retainer set adrift by the downfall of his lord) of Yoshitsura repeatedly rose up in revolt in various places asking for restoration of the direct line of descent of the Isshiki family.

Even after that, however, ishin (retainer set adrift by the downfall of his lord) of Yoshitsura repeatedly rose up in revolt in various places asking for restoration of the direct line of descents of the Isshiki family.

Even after that, however, ishin (retainer set adrift by the downfall of his lord) of Yoshitsura repeatedly rose up in revolt in various places asking for restoration of the direct line of descents of the Isshiki family.

sen.j: 嘉吉元年（1441年）の一色氏旧守護国三河・若狭での国人蜂起、翌年12月の延永氏の京都北野天満宮立て篭もり事件、文安元年（1444年）の氏家氏の叛乱未遂事件などがそれである。
sen.e: Examples of such revolt are seen in the revolt in 1441 by indigenous persons in Mikawa and Wakasa for which the Isshiki clan was the shugo, occupation of Kitano-tenmangu Shrine in December, next year by the Nobunaga clan, and failed attempt of revolt in 1444 by the Ujiie clan in December, next year,

Examples of such revolts can be seen in the revolt in 1441 by indigenous persons in Mikawa and Wakasa for which the Isshiki clan was the shugo, occupation of Kitano-tenmangu Shrine in December, and the next year by the Nobunaga clan, and a failed attempt at revolt in 1444 by the Ujiie clan in December, the next year,

Examples of such revolts can be seen in the revolt in 1441 by indigenous persons in Mikawa and Wakasa Provinces for which the Isshiki clan was the shugo, occupation of Kitano-tenmangu Shrine in December, and the next year by the Nobunaga clan, and a failed attempt at revolt in 1444 by the Ujiie clan in December, the next year.
sen.cmt: 文末のカンマ→ピリオドに修正、Mikawa and Wakasa→Mikawa and Wakaa Provincesとしました。

sen.j: 宝徳3年（1451年）、一色教親は33歳の若さで没し、嗣子が無かったため、嫡流である義直が家督を継ぐこととなり、ここに義貫遺臣の願いは達成された。
sen.e: In 1451, Norichika ISSHIKI died young at the age of thirty-three and, as he had no heir, Yoshinao, who belonged to the direct line of descent inherited the headship of the family and therefore the wish of the ishin of Yoshitsura was met.

In 1451, Norichika ISSHIKI died young at the age of thirty-three and, as he had no heir, Yoshinao, who belonged to the direct line of descents inherited the head of the family, thereby fulfilling Yoshitsura's wish of the ishin.

In 1451, Norichika ISSHIKI died young at the age of thirty-three and, as he had no heir, Yoshinao, who belonged to the direct line of descents inherited the head of the family, thereby fulfilling Yoshitsura's wish of the ishin.

sen.j: 義直は教親の領国のうち、丹後・伊勢半国・尾張知多郡を受け継ぎ（尾張海東郡のみ外される）、三河国渥美郡、同じく旧守護国若狭国小浜も知行地として手に入れる。
sen.e: Out of fiefs of Norichika, Yoshinao inherited Tango Province, a half of Ise Province, Kato District, Owari Province (but, only Kaito District, Owari Province was excluded) and also acquired Atsumi District, Mikawa Province, and Obama, Wakasa Province, which was former territory for shugoshoku.

Out of fiefs for Norichika, Yoshinao inherited Tango Province, a half of Ise Province, Kato District, Owari Province (but, only Kaito District, Owari Province was excluded) and also acquired Atsumi District, Mikawa Province, and Obama, Wakasa Province, which was the former territory for shugoshoku.

Out of fiefs for Norichika, Yoshinao inherited Tango Province, a half of Ise Province, Chita District, Owari Province (but, only Kaito District, Owari Province was excluded) and also acquired Atsumi District, Mikawa Province, and Obama, Wakasa Province, which was the former territory for shugo.
sen.cmt: Kato District→Chita Districtに修正、for shugoshoku→for shugoとしました。

sen.j: 幕府においては、御相伴衆となり将軍足利義政の信頼を得、寛正年間は毎年2月17日に義直の京屋形に義政が訪れるのが慣例となっていた（『蔭凉軒日録』）。
sen.e: In the bakufu (shogunate), he assumed the position of oshobanshu (senior representative) and acquired trust of Yoshimasa ASHIKAGA, who was shogun and, during Kansho era, it was a custom that Yoshimasa visits Yoshinao's kyoyakata (mansion in Kyoto) (Inryoken Nichiroku (Diary of the owner of Inryoken).

In the bakufu (shogunate), he assumed the position of oshobanshu (senior representative) and acquired the trust of Yoshimasa ASHIKAGA, who was shogun and, during Kansho era, it was a customary that Yoshimasa visit Yoshinao's kyoyakata (mansion in Kyoto) (Inryoken Nichiroku (Diary of the owner of Inryoken).

In the bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), he assumed the position of oshobanshu (senior representative) and acquired the trust of Yoshimasa ASHIKAGA, who was shogun and, during Kansho era, it was a customary that Yoshimasa visit Yoshinao's kyoyakata (mansion in Kyoto) ("Inryoken Nichiroku," a diary of the owner of Inryoken).
sen.cmt: 余分なスペース消去、bakufuの補足を統一表記に修正、（『蔭凉軒日録』）の表記修正

sen.j: しかし、応仁の乱では旧守護国若狭・三河を復旧するため、西軍山名宗全に味方したため、東軍を支持する義政により全ての領国の守護職を解かれる。
sen.e: In the Onin War, however, he took Sozen YAMANA's side, West Squad, in order to recover Wakasa Province and Mikawa Province, which previously were fiefs for shugo, and therefore, he was dismissed all shugoshoku for fiefs by Yoshimasa wno supported the East Squad.

In the Onin War, however, he took Sozen YAMANA's side, West Squad, in order to recover Wakasa Province and Mikawa Province, which previously were fiefs for shugo, and therefore, he dismissed all shugoshoku for fiefs by Yoshimasa wno supported the East Squad.

In the Onin War, however, he took Sozen YAMANA's side, West Squad, in order to recover Wakasa Province and Mikawa Province, which previously were fiefs for shugo, and therefore, he dismissed all shugoshiki (post of provincial constable) for fiefs by Yoshimasa wno supported the East Squad.
sen.cmt: shgoshoku→shugoshikiとし、補足追加 (用語集参照)

sen.j: 本国丹後では新守護武田信賢と一色氏守護代延永氏の激戦が続き、伊勢でも新守護土岐政康と一色氏守護代石河道悟との合戦が続いた。
sen.e: In Tango Province, which was the home country, the fierce battle between the new shugo, Nobukata TAKEDA, and the shugodai (deputy constable) of the Isshiki clan, the Nobukata TAKEDA continued and, also in Ise, the battle between the new shugo, Masayasu TOKI and the shugodai of the Isshiki clan, Dogo ISHIKAWA continued.

In the Tango Province, which was his home country, the fierce battle between the new shugo, Nobukata TAKEDA, and the shugodai (deputy constable) of the Isshiki clan, the Nobukata TAKEDA continued and, also in Ise, the battle between the new shugo, Masayasu TOKI and the shugodai of the Isshiki clan, Dogo ISHIKAWA continued.

In the Tango Province, which was his home country, the fierce battle between the new shugo, Nobukata TAKEDA, and the shugodai (deputy constable) of the Isshiki clan, the Nobukata TAKEDA continued and, also in Ise, the battle between the new shugo, Masayasu TOKI and the shugodai (deputy of provincial constable) of the Isshiki clan, Dogo ISHIKAWA continued.

sen.j: 逆に細川成之の領する三河には弟一色義遠が率いる軍勢が尾張知多郡から侵攻、ここでも激戦が続いている。
sen.e: Contrarily to above-mentioned cases, in Mikawa province which was controlled by Shigeyuki HOSOKAWA, the troop under the command of Yoshinao's younger brother, marched in and fierce battle continued also in this Province.

Contrarily to the above-mentioned cases, in Mikawa province which was controlled by Shigeyuki HOSOKAWA, the troops under the command of Yoshinao's younger brother, marched in and a fierce battle continued in the Province.

Contrarily to the above-mentioned cases, in Mikawa Province which was controlled by Shigeyuki HOSOKAWA, the troops under the command of Yoshinao's younger brother, marched in and a fierce battle continued in the Province.
sen.cmt: provinceの頭文字を大文字に統一

sen.j: 文明 (日本)6年（1474年）4月、細川勝元と山名政豊の間で和議が成立すると、義直は東軍に帰順、隠退し、嫡男義春を幕府に出仕させる。
sen.e: In April 1474, when Katsumoto HOSOKAWA and Masatoyo YAMANA concluded a peace with each other, Yoshinao returned to his former allegiance and retired and made his heir, Yoshiharu, serve the bakufu.

In April 1474, when Katsumoto HOSOKAWA and Masatoyo YAMANA concluded a peace agreement with each other, Yoshinao returned to his former allegience, retired and made his heir, Yoshiharu, serve the bakufu.

In April 1474, when Katsumoto HOSOKAWA and Masatoyo YAMANA concluded a peace agreement with each other, Yoshinao returned to his former allegience, retired and made his heir, Yoshiharu, serve the bakufu.

sen.j: 同年、幕府は丹後守護職を義春に返付、勢いづいた丹後の一色勢は同国に駐屯していた武田勢を破り、旧領回復に成功する。
sen.e: In the same year, the bakufu returned the tango shugoshoku to Yoshiharu and the invigorated troop of the Isshiki clan in Tango Province defeated the troop of the Takeda clan stationed in Tango Province and succeeded to recover the former fief.

In the same year, the bakufu returned the tango shugoshoku to Yoshiharu and the invigorated troops of the Isshiki clan in Tango Province defeated the troops of the Takeda clan stationed in Tango Province and succeeded to recover their former fief.

In the same year, the bakufu returned the shugoshiki for Tango Province to Yoshiharu and the invigorated troops of the Isshiki clan in Tango Province defeated the troops of the Takeda clan stationed in Tango Province and succeeded to recover their former fief.
sen.cmt: the tango shugoshoku→the shugoshiki for Tango Provinceとしました。

sen.j: 三河では文明8年（1476年）、一色勢が細川成之の守護代東条国氏を自害に追い込み優勢であったが、成之はこの事件を契機に幕府出仕を拒否した。
sen.e: In Mikawa Province, the troop of the Isshiki clan compelled Kuniuji TOJO, who was the shugodai of Shigeyuki HOSOKAWA, to commit a suicide and held advantage, but, with this as a turning point, Shigeyuki refused to attend the bakufu.
sen.cmt: 原文を二つに分割しました。
sen.e: In Mikawa Province, the troops of the Isshiki clan compelled Kuniuji TOJO, who was the shugodai of Shigeyuki HOSOKAWA, to commit suicide and thus held an advantage, which was a turning point that prompted Shigeyuki to refuse to attend the bakufu.

In Mikawa Province, the troops of the Isshiki clan compelled Kuniuji TOJO, who was the shugodai of Shigeyuki HOSOKAWA, to commit suicide and thus held an advantage, which was a turning point that prompted Shigeyuki to refuse to attend the bakufu.

sen.j: 結局、文明10年（1478年）2月、義直が三河を放棄する旨、文書で表明し三河の一色軍は撤退した。
sen.e: Finally, in February 1478, Yoshinao declared in writing that he gave up Mikawa Province and the troop of the Isshiki clan in Mikawa Province retreated.
sen.cmt: 原文を二つに分割しました。
sen.e: Finally, in February 1478, Yoshinao declared in writing that he gave up Mikawa Province and the troops of the Isshiki clan in Mikawa Province retreated.
Finally, in February 1478, Yoshinao declared in writing that he gave up Mikawa Province and the troops of the Isshiki clan in Mikawa Province retreated.

sen.j: 伊勢では、義春に半国守護職が与えられたが、これに反撥する北畠家との戦いに敗れている。
sen.e: In Ise Province, the shugoshoku of the half of the Ise Province was given to Yoshiharu, but they lost the battle with the Kitabakake family which opposed to it.
In Ise Province, the shugoshoku of the half of the Ise Province was given to Yoshiharu, but they lost the battle with the Kitabakake family which were opposed to it.
In Ise Province, the shugoshiki of the half of the Ise Province was given to Yoshiharu, but they lost the battle with the Kitabakake family which were opposed to it.

sen.j: 三河を放棄した文明10年に義直は幕府に再出仕し、義春を後見したが、義春は文明16年（1484年）に19歳の若さで没し、丹後守護職のみ義直に再度与えられた。
sen.e: In 1478 in which the Mikawa Province was given up, Yoshinao served the bakufu again and acted as a guardian for Yoshiharu, but Yoshiharu died young in 1484 at the age of nineteen and only the shugoshoku for Tango Province was given to Yoshinao again.

In 1478, which was the date in which Mikawa Province was given up, Yoshinao served the bakufu again and acted as guardian for Yoshiharu, but Yoshiharu died young in 1484 at the age of nineteen and only the shugoshoku for Tango Province was given to Yoshinao again.

In 1478, which was the date in which Mikawa Province was given up, Yoshinao served the bakufu again and acted as guardian for Yoshiharu, but Yoshiharu died young in 1484 at the age of nineteen and only the shugoshiki for Tango Province was given to Yoshinao again.

sen.j: 文明18年（1486年）8月、禁裏の意向により義直の知行地である若狭国小浜が武田国信に与えられると、抗議のため丹後へ下向、翌長享元年（1487年）の足利義尚による六角高頼攻めにも参陣せず、代理に子の義秀を参陣させた。
sen.e: In August 1486, when the Obama, Wakasa Province, which had been Yoshinao's fief, was given to Kuninobu TAKEDA according to the wish of the imperial palace, Yoshinao went down to Tango Province to protest it and he did not join the attack against Takayori ROKKAKU by Yoshihisa ASHIKAGA and sent his son, Yoshihide, instead.

In August 1486, when Obama, Wakasa Province, which had been Yoshinao's fief, was given to Kuninobu TAKEDA according to the wishes of the imperial palace, Yoshinao went down to Tango Province to protest it and did not join the attack against Takayori ROKKAKU by Yoshihisa ASHIKAGA and sent his son, Yoshihide, instead.

In August 1486, when Obama, Wakasa Province, which had been Yoshinao's fief, was given to Kuninobu TAKEDA according to the wishes of the imperial palace, Yoshinao went down to Tango Province to protest it and did not join the attack against Takayori ROKKAKU by Yoshihisa ASHIKAGA in 1487 and sent his son, Yoshihide, instead.

sen.j: しかし、延徳3年（1491年）の足利義稙による六角攻めには自身で参陣し、義材に代わり首実検を行っている。
sen.e: However, Yoshinao himself joined the attack against Rokkaku in 1491 by Yoshitane ASHIKAGA and he did kubijikken (identifying a severed head) in place of Yoshiki.
However, Yoshinao himself joined the attack against Rokkaku in 1491 by Yoshitane ASHIKAGA and carried out kubijikken (identifying a severed head) in place of Yoshiki.
However, Yoshinao himself joined the attack against Rokkaku in 1491 by Yoshitane ASHIKAGA and carried out kubijikken (identifying a severed head) in place of Yoshiki.

sen.j: 明応元年（1492年）12月、義材の帰洛に従いしばらく在京していたが、翌明応2年（1493年）正月、丹後で伊賀次郎左衛門の叛乱が勃発、鎮圧のため下向し、以後の消息は不明となる。
sen.e: In December 1492, following Yoshiki's return to Kyoto, Yoshiharu stayed in Kyoto for certain period, but, in January 1493, when revolt by Jirosaemon IGA occurred in Tango Province, he went down to suppress the revolt and, after that, he became untraceable.

In December 1492, following Yoshiki's return to Kyoto, Yoshiharu stayed in Kyoto for a certain period, but, in January 1493, when a revolt by Jirosaemon IGA occurred in Tango Province, he went down to suppress the revolt and, after that, became untraceable.

In December 1492, following Yoshiki's return to Kyoto, Yoshiharu stayed in Kyoto for a certain period, but, in January 1493, when a revolt by Jirosaemon IGA occurred in Tango Province, he went down to suppress the revolt and, after that, became untraceable.
